Fig. 1 Thermogravimetric analysis of (a) Co-rich, (b) un-modified and (c) Cr-rich synthesized catalysts calcined at 450 °C, with heat flow and weight variations as functions of the temperature. Note that the blue plot is read on the left-y-axis and that the black one is read on the right-y-axis. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Adsorption/desorption isotherms and BJH pore size distribution for Co-rich (red), Cr-rich (green) and un-modified (blue) catalysts calcined at 450 °C (a) and (b) and at 685 °C (c) and (d), respectively. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Comparison of the XRD diffractograms for un-modified (CoCr2O4) and Co-/Cr-rich (Co-CoCr2O4 and Cr-CoCr2O4) catalysts calcined at 450 °C and 685 °C and the associated Miller indexes. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 HRTEM images of (a) un-modified CoCr2O4 and (b) Cr-rich Cr-CoCr2O4 catalysts calcined at 450 °C and (c) and (d) Co-rich Co-CoCr2O4 catalyst calcined at 450 °C and 685 °C, respectively. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 XPS profiles of (a) Cr 2p, (b) Co 2p and (c) O 1 s for Co-rich (top), un-modified (midst) and Cr-rich (bottom) catalysts calcined at 450 °C. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 XPS profiles of (a) Cr 2p, (b) Co 2p and (c) O 1 s for Co-rich catalyst calcined at 685 °C. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 H2-TPR profiles for (a) the Co-rich, un-modified and Cr-rich catalysts calcined at 450 °C, and (b) the two former catalysts calcined at 685 ºC. The inserted values are the reduction peak temperatures and the dotted line separates the low- and high-temperature regions. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Toluene conversion as a function of reaction temperature during the third cooling ramp of the un-modified, Co-rich and Cr-rich catalysts calcined at 450 °C and 685 °C. China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Un-supported spinel-type cobalt chromite catalysts were synthetized by propionic acid-mediated sol-gel method and tested for toluene oxidation. The influence of the Co and Cr content and the preparation conditions on physico-chemical, surface and catalytic properties for this reaction has been for the first time evaluated. Co-rich CoCr2O4 was the most active catalyst, likely due to the formation of a single CoCr2O4 spinel phase, a favorable surface composition and higher low-temperature reducibility. Besides, the increase of the calcination temperature, despite worsening textural properties, also has a promoting effect on the catalytic activity by preserving a suitable reducibility and further enhancing the surface properties. Surface Cr6+ ions and adsorbed oxygens (Oads), which are more abundant in the most efficient catalyst (Co-rich catalyst calcined at 685 °C), seem to play an important role on toluene oxidation reaction. These findings may open potential strategies in the development of efficient and economically competitive catalysts for elimination of VOCs like toluene. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Cobalt and chromium doping Chromite spinel oxides Sol-gel method Volatile organic compounds Toluene combustion Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction Air pollutants emissions are closely monitored through environmental restriction laws because of their contribution to climate change (such as CO2 or CH4) and health impact (NO2, O3, etc). In this global warming context and the concerning rising awareness of the ordinary citizen, pollutants emissions tend to be more restrictive regardless of the sector (transports, energy production, industries, agriculture…). Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs) are volatile hydrocarbon molecules considered as air pollutants due to their harmfulness to human health, depending on their air concentration and population’s exposure. Among them, one can find the BTEX category (standing for " Benzene, Toluene, Ethylbenzene and Xylene "), which are emitted in the atmosphere by various industrial sources (chemical plants, refineries, industrial food processes, transportation, agricultural processes), but also in indoor air by paints, insulation materials, cleaning products, furniture [1,2]. Particularly, toluene (C7H8) is one of the most common molecules presented in indoor air and, at high exposure, it can cause nausea, headaches and even damage the neurological system. So, their emissions are strictly regulated, which requires efficient processes for VOCs treatment or abatement to prevent the population from their toxicity. Catalytic total oxidation, which is one of the most promising technology for VOCs removal, consists of transforming them into water vapor and carbon dioxide (less toxic). However, the large variety of VOCs nature and composition requires specific catalyst developments for each targeted pollutant. A signiﬁcant number of researches have been carried out towards the removal of VOCs via catalytic oxidation in recent years [1,2]. The effectiveness of noble metal-based catalysts, mainly supported platinum, palladium and gold-based catalysts, for catalytic total oxidation of toluene has been claimed by several authors [1–4]. However, the industrial application of these noble metal-based catalysts is limited by their high cost, low thermal stability and poor resistance to sulfur and chlorine poison species, which spotlights the need for more low-cost efficient and stable catalysts. In this sense, spinel oxide-type catalysts, with a generic formula of AB2O4, where A is a bivalent transition metal cation, B is a trivalent one and O is an oxygen atom, have shown some promising abilities for VOCs combustion [5–11], particularly Chlorinated volatile organic compounds (CVOCs) oxidation, due to their high activity at low operating temperature and excellent thermal stability. They are also used as catalytic removals for diesel soot and NOx [12], or even for unburned methane in compressed-natural-gas vehicles [13]. The choice of spinel oxide-type materials is currently motivated by their typically reported high specific surface area and the synergetic effect of combining several transition metals in a homogeneous controlled crystalline matrix [6,10,11]. Indeed, rather than the textural properties, catalyst structure is in some cases the most determining in the catalytic behaviour, by favouring the catalyst reducibility, oxygen mobility and the formation of active oxygen species, leading rise to higher catalytic activity of these oxides [7,10,14]. In the present work, un-supported spinel-type cobalt chromite oxide catalysts have been selected for the investigation of the low-temperature toluene oxidation, given the proven catalytic performance of this kind of catalysts for the combustion of other VOCs like methane [7,13,15], trichloroethylene [11] or dichloromethane [6,10]. There is also one work from Spassova et al. [16], where copper and cobalt chromite catalysts, prepared by a conventional impregnation method, were tested for toluene oxidation. Interestingly, in that work, the authors showed signs that the catalytic activity was strongly affected by the spinel phases (either CuCr2O4 or CoCr2O4), rather than by the presence of oxide phases (either CuO or Co2O3, respectively) or by the nature of the support (γ-Al2O3, SiO2). However, neither the transition metal ratios nor the catalyst synthesis procedure was investigated. It must be noted that the preparation method of these spinel-based oxides, including precursors and operating conditions, likely influence their physicochemical properties, the distribution of substituted ions (i.e. Cr3+/6+, Co2+/3+) among octahedral (Oh) and tetrahedral (Td) sites and, as a consequence, the catalytic activity [14,17–19]. Besides, in the present work, the enrichment of CoCr2O4 with either Co or Cr will be also explored. In this way, a potential improvement of the interaction (synergistic effect) between the ion (Co or Cr) confined in the parent structure (CoCr2O4) and those which enrich the surface (Co-rich and Cr-rich catalysts) will be investigated. A similar phenomenon has already been found on Cu/CuCr2O4 catalysts [20,21]. In the present study, propionic acid, which is considered a good liquid chelating agent, is used as a precursor through sol-gel process [22]. This enables the “direct” polymerization, controlling hydrolysis and condensation reactions [23], stabilizing the resulting sol to obtain homogeneous gels. Previous works based on sol-gel process using liquid propionic acid as precursor have been done for the synthesis of cobalt oxide [24] and IrRhTiOx or RhRuTiOx catalysts [18], but to our knowledge, this is the first time that this chelating agent is employed for cobalt chromite synthesis. Moreover, the catalyst reducibility, which is a key parameter in the VOCs reaction mechanism as evidenced by some authors [6,10], could be modified by changing the chemical composition or ions distribution. With the Co/Cr ratio decrease, ions substitutions (Co3+ by Cr3+/6+) happening in octahedral sites are responsible for the spinel structure disorganization because of their different ionic radii (Jahn-Teller effect) [6,9]. Since octahedrally coordinated cations sites are exposed on the surface of the structure, they usually play a key role in the reaction mechanism because of their close interactions with the pollutant, and the VOCs reaction rate seems to depend on the surface density of Cr6+ [6]. According to the literature, the Mars and Van Krevelen (MVK) redox type mechanism [5,25–28] likely takes place in the VOCs oxidation process, which involves lattice oxygens and their mobility inside the spinel (increased with Jahn-Teller effect) [10]. Additionally, the structural and physicochemical properties are expected to be very sensitive to certain operation parameters. For example, the calcination temperature usually affects the specific surface area due to the modification of the lattice parameter (due to substitution of Co3+ by Cr3+/6+ (Oh)) [10], and is linked to the transition from an amorphous phase to a spinel structure, which seems to happen at about 380 °C [29]. Thus, the main goal of this study is to evaluate the cobalt- and chromium-enrichment and its influence on the spinel structure. We aim to unravel whether the synthesized materials are constituted of two (or more) distinct phases side-by-side (chromium/cobalt oxides attached to the spinel phase) or if the oxides are immersed in the spinel structure. The influence of this single or secondary oxides phase on physico-chemical, redox and catalytic properties was consequently evaluated. In this way, different catalysts either with stoichiometric Co/Cr at. ratio (1:2) or enriched in Co or Cr were synthetized, characterized and tested in toluene total oxidation reaction. Moreover, all the catalysts were also tested after different calcination temperatures. Thus, the impact of an increase in either cobalt or chromium content and calcination temperature on cobalt chromite spinel oxide catalytic performance has been evaluated, for the first time, for the toluene oxidation reaction, by also assessing the consequent effects on the physico-chemical and redox properties of these materials. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts (Sol-Gel synthesis method) Three catalysts were synthetized by sol-gel method with different Co/Cr molar ratios (1:1, 1:2 and 1:3), which are denoted as Co-CoCr2O4 (Co-rich catalysts), CoCr2O4 (un-modified catalyst) and Cr-CoCr2O4 (Cr-rich catalyst), respectively [30]. Thus, a stochiometric composition (Co/Cr at. ratio of 1:2) was used to synthetized the catalyst denoted as un-modified catalyst, whereas for Co-rich or Cr-rich catalysts, the amount of Co or Cr precursors salts were adjusted to obtain an excess of Co or Cr (at. ratio of 1:1 and 1:3, respectively) compared to stochiometric cobalt chromite. The synthesis of cobalt- and chromium-rich spinel catalysts was already accomplished by co-precipitation method previously reported by Kim and Ihm [11]. In the present work, chrome(III) acetylacetonate and cobalt(II) acetylacetonate were used as precursors salts. Note that the composition of all cobalt chromite presented in this work was adjusted by addition, at the first step of the synthesis, of a specific amount of these Co or Cr precursors on the cobalt chromite gel. On the other hand, the propionic acid was used both as liquid chelating agent and solvent, presenting a dual function. The advantage of the latter, compared to others used in literature (such citric acid), is that herein the polymerisation takes place by itself, controlling hydrolysis (1) and condensation (2) reactions [23]. (1) M(OR)z + x·XOH = [M(OR)z-x, (OX)x] + x ROH, with X = H (2) M-OR + H2O → M-OH + R-OH Note that M is a n state oxidation metal and OR an alkoxide group. Propionate ions are linked to Co2+ ions to gradually form the cobalt propionate gel, which is formed in excess of propionic acid. The latter also have the role of solvent. Starting metals salts are first dissolved, and then the hydrolysis is conducted to form linear, cyclic, or ramified M-O-M binding, producing a gel by controlled and progressive evaporation of the propionic acid. During the condensation phase by evaporation of the solution, which leads to a gel, the propionic acid (solvent) is recovered by distillation for reuse. This gel is treated with liquid nitrogen then shredded and calcined allowing the elimination of the organic part and forming the final oxide. As previously mentioned in the introduction, the preparation method, including precursors and operating conditions, can have an important influence on the formation of the spinel-based oxides [14,17–19]. Thus, it is worth to mention that the ratio of propionic acid (as chelating agent and as a solvent), the hydrolysis step (amount and speed of addition of H2O to the solution under stirring) for gel formation and the rate of decomposition of the gel (under N2 in order to avoid excessive temperature gradient or in the presence of air), were firstly studied and optimized on the basis of TG-DTA and FTIR spectroscopy measurements. These parameters are some of the most important parameters of the sol-gel synthesis method, allow the control of the spinel structure formation according to the literature [30–33]. Thus, an optimal ratio of propionic acid/cobalt or chromium precursors of ca. 30/1 (wt./wt.) was obtained and used for all the synthesized catalysts. Moreover, the exchange of acetylacetonate and propionate groups of the formed gel after evaporation of the solvent was insured by FTIR measurements. The hydrolysis step (amount and speed of addition of H2O to the solution under stirring) was performed using a RAZEL syringe pump (Scientific Instruments. INC (USA)) for gel formation. The optimized values in this step were: 7% H2O with respect to propionic acid (vol./vol.) and a speed addition of 4 mL/h (syringe of max. capacity of 30 mL) during mechanical stirring with a total time of stirring of 90 min. Finally, the parameters of precursor decomposition (dried gel) and calcination processes were optimized by TG-DTA analysis. Thus, the synthetized catalysts were calcined at two different temperatures, 450 °C and 685 °C, performing a calcination in two consecutive steps: i) first one under N2 until 300 °C (in order to avoid excessive temperature gradient during precursor decomposition) and ii) second one (calcinations at high temperature 450 °C or 685 °C) in the presence of air in order to obtain the crystalline phases of cobalt chromite (un-modified, Co-rich and Cr-rich catalysts). Thus, a total of five different catalysts were prepared under these optimized operating conditions in order to evaluate the influence of catalyst composition and calcination temperature. 2.2 Catalysts characterization Several characterization measurements, including X-ray diffraction (XRD), thermogravimetric analysis, various spectroscopies (ICP-OES, XPS), N2 adsorption isotherms, electron microscopy (TEM) and H2-temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) were conducted to finely analyse the structure and chemical reactivity of the materials. The following protocols were used to carry out the catalyst characterisation. Bulk composition of the catalysts was determined by Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectrometry (ICP-OES) from HORIBA Jobin Yvon Activa equipped with a CCD detector. Precursor decomposition was evaluated in nitrogen using a Perkin Elmer-Pyris Diamond TG-DTA analyzer. The samples (ca. 20 mg) were placed in platinum crucible and heated up to 700 °C (5 °C·min−1) with a flow rate of 7 L h−1. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the catalysts were measured using a Bruker D5005 diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα (λ = 0.15418 nm). The scan range was from 4 to 80° (2θ) with a step size of 0.02° for a total acquisition time of 32 min. The Diffrac.Eva software (Bruker) and the ICDD-PDF4 + database were used to identify the different phases and to determine the lattice parameters and crystallinity of the catalysts. The nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms were measured at 77 K on a Micromeritics Tristar 3000 surface area and porosity analyzer after degassing at 200 °C for 5 h. The specific surface area and the pore size distribution of each catalyst were calculated from the linear part of Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJK) methods, respectively. Note that these BET measurements were repeated to validate them. An experimental error of 5% was estimated. Hydrogen Temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were performed to measure the reduction properties of the catalysts on TPD/R/O 1100 (Thermo Scientific) apparatus. 0.20 g sample was placed in a quartz reactor, fastened between quartz wool plugs, and flowed over by the reducing gas (5 vol% H2/Ar) with a flow rate of 40 mL min−1 . The temperature range was from 25 to 900 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The water produced during the reduction was removed with a molecular sieve (5 A, Thermo Scientific) trap. The amount of H2 uptake in the process was measured using a Thermal conductivity detector (TCD), previously calibrated by carrying out H2-TPR measurements with CuO standard (Merk). Before the analysis, the samples were pre-treated at 450 °C for 2 h with a gas flow of Ar (flow rate of 60 mL min−1). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) observations of the catalysts were performed on a JEOL 2010 LaB6. The specimen for TEM was prepared by grinding the catalyst into powder in a mortar, dispersing it in ethanol and placing a droplet of the suspension onto a copper grid coated with a carbon. Surface composition and oxidation state of catalysts were evaluated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). These experiments were carried out on a Thermo ESCALAB 250 electron spectrometer using an Al Kα (1486.6 eV) radiation source. The constant charging of the XPS spectra was corrected by C1s of adventitious carbon with binding energy of 284.8 ± 0.8 eV. 2.3 Catalytic conversion of toluene Light-off tests (succession of heating and cooling ramps without any plateau) have been conducted to compare the catalytic activity of the five different synthesized catalysts and their stability. Catalytic runs were performed with 0.1 g of catalysts at temperatures ranging from 25° to 450°C (ramps of 2 °C min−1) using 1000 ppm toluene in air and a total flow rate of 100 mL min−1. The concentration of reactants was adjusted by using a saturator coupled with Corto CD20F cryothermostat (Julabo, Seelbach, Germany) for toluene and by mass flow controllers (BROOKS) for synthetic air (80/20 vol%). All catalysts were also tested upon cooling the reactor down to room temperature. The catalyst was incorporated over a quartz wool plug in a U-type reactor. There consecutive catalytic runs were performed in order to evaluate the stability of each catalyst. Finally, the catalytic activity of the best-performing catalyst was also evaluated in the presence of steam by introducing 5 vol% H2O in the reaction system. The toluene conversion was followed through CO and CO2 production measurements by means of an on-line IR analyser (ROSEMOUNT Xstream), according to reaction (3). (3) C7H8 + 9 O2 → 7 CO2 + 4 H2O The toluene conversion (XT, in %) was estimated through Eq. (4): (4) X T = C CO 2 x 100 7 x C T , 0 Where CT,0 is the initial toluene concentration and CCO2 is the CO2 concentration measured in the outlet stream at a time t. Note that the initial concentration of toluene was analyzed by gas chromatography (CPG, PERKIN ELMER Clarus 500) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and TCD, using a capillary column (Chromosorb 101) for organic gas separation and a packing column (Carboxen 1000) for permanent gas separation. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterisation results 3.1.1 Elemental analysis (ICP-OES), Thermogravimetric and differential thermal analyses (TGA/DTG) and N2-sorption Firstly, the loss of mass during the decomposition of Co and/or Cr propionate precursors was studied by thermogravimetric analysis in N2 at atmospheric pressure and controlled heating rates. The TGA/DTG curves of Co-, Cr-rich and un-modified catalysts calcined at 450 ºC are plotted in Fig. 1(a-c). Enthalpy measurements are expressed in J/g, Fig. 1(a-c). The weight loss at 700 ºC was almost the same for all un-modified and modified catalysts (ca. 65%, Table 1). After water and free propionic acid removal at temperature T < 200 °C, one can distinguish three main different exothermic heat flow peaks appearing on all the above profiles. The first one at 400 °C is related to the cobalt propionate decomposition and the second one at 450 °C to the chromium propionate one [34]. Indeed, the chromium propionate peak area and so the corresponding decomposition heat increase whereas the cobalt one decreases as the cobalt chromite oxide is modified with additional chromium (Fig. 1c vs. b and a), due to the higher amount of chromium precursor to be decomposed. With the same reasoning, the area of the cobalt propionate decomposition peak increases with Co content (the highest in Fig. 1a). Another peak that emerges near 650 °C could be associated with the changes in the oxidation state of formed chromium and cobalt oxides and, specifically, with some Cr or Co oxidation process, as there are no more impurities to eliminate at those temperature ranges. The chemical composition and textural properties measured by ICP-OES and N2-adsorption analyses, respectively, are presented in Table 1. ICP-OES analyses confirmed the Co/Cr molar ratio in those three catalysts almost as planned: Co/Cr = 0.984 for the Co-rich, 0.493 for the un-modified and 0.352 for the Cr-rich catalysts. In addition, the chemical composition was maintained after calcination at high temperature (685 °C), observing a Co/Cr molar ratio = 0.961 and 0.465 for the Co-rich and un-modified, respectively. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) pore diameter distribution of un-modified and Co- or Cr-rich catalysts calcined at 450 °C are presented in Fig. 2(a, b). According to IUPAC classification [35], the catalysts showed a characteristic type IV adsorption/desorption isotherm, Fig. 2(a), which reveals a signature of mesoporosity. The non-reversibility of these isotherms indicates the presence of pores larger than 2 nm, which is further confirmed by the pore diameter distributions in Fig. 2(b). A hysteresis loops type H3 is observed for all catalysts, which is also associated with mesoporous materials [35]. The specific surface area, total volume pore and pore size of each catalyst could be calculated by using Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and BJH methods, respectively. Thus, the un-modified CoCr2O4 catalyst presented a narrow pore diameter distribution centered at 6 nm, whereas a dual pores size distribution was observed for both modified catalysts, with a clearer separation between the two pore sizes in the Cr-rich one. Moreover, it also appears that adding either Co or Cr affects the porosity of the catalysts through increasing their pore diameters (Fig. 2(b) and Table 1), which could be indicative of the incorporation of part of the cobalt and/or chromium oxides within the mesoporous framework of raw cobalt chromite material. As shown in Table 1, the specific surface, was decreased by Co or Cr addition, according to the literature [7,10,15]. For example, Chen et al. [7] explored different Co/Cr at. Ratios between 1:5 and 5:1 and they obtained the maximum specific surface area (38.6 m2 g−1) for the same optimum composition (Co/Cr of 1:2). However, the total pore volume was generally preserved after ions addition. Then, the un-modified CoCr2O4 catalyst and the most active one, Co-CoCr2O4 catalyst, were also calcined at high temperature (685 °C) to evaluate the effect of the calcination temperature. The textural properties were also evaluated and are reported in Fig. 2 and Table 1. These catalysts also showed the characteristic mesoporous type IV isotherms, according to IUPAC classification. However, the specific surface area and total volume pore decreased, while the pore size diameters increased, compared to those of the catalysts calcined at low temperature (450 °C), which can be attributed to the particles sintering during the calcination [17,36]. Moreover, according to the literature, this decrease of specific surface area can be also associated with the enhancement of the lattice parameter (due to substitution of Co3+ by Cr3+/6+ (Oh)) [10]. The fact that the most efficient catalyst (Co-rich catalyst) calcined at 685 °C, as it will be presented below, has the lowest specific surface area clearly indicates that this parameter, which is considered as one of the most important ones in heterogenous catalysis, is not the only one that has influence on the catalytic activity of these kinds of materials. 3.1.2 X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) and Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) The XRD patterns in Fig. 3 demonstrate that the cobalt chromite CoCr2O4 phase in cubic spinel-type structure (F3dm group symmetry) was the main phase presented in all the catalysts, according to the literature (reference pattern: JCPDS 22–1084 for standard cobalt chromite CoCr2O4) [10,37–41]. Nevertheless, one can also find a small amount of chromium oxide (Eskolaite, syn-Cr2O3 (JCPDS 38–1479) and cobalt oxide (Spinel, syn-Co2.74O4 (JCPDS 78–5614)) peaks [39], especially in the chromium-rich and un-modified catalysts. This indicates that a second phase may be formed in these two catalysts. Nevertheless, no peaks other than spinel phase were detected for Co-rich catalysts, which indicates the formation of pure CoCr2O4 phase in this case [40]. HRTEM images seem to corroborate the presence of CoCr2O4 in all the catalysts, identified by lattice spacing in Fig. 4(a-c). The lattice fringes with 0.48 nm spacing correspond to the (111) planes of CoCr2O4, whereas the lattice spacing of 0.24 nm is assigned to the (311) planes [39,42]. In addition, the presence of chromium oxide on the surface of un-modified catalyst is also corroborated by lattice spacing of ca. 0.27 and 0.36 nm, which are representative of (104) and (012) planes of Cr2O3 phase [43]. The latter is clearly observed in Fig. 4(a). Some evidences of the presence of cobalt oxide are observed in Fig. 4(b) for Cr-rich catalyst, in which the lattice spacing of 0.40 nm, assigned to the (200) planes of Co3O4 phase, is clearly observed [39]. On the other hand, only the (111) and (311) planes of CoCr2O4 phase are clearly observed in HRTEM images for Co-rich chromite catalysts, Fig. 4(c, d) [39]. Again, no phases other than spinel are clearly observed for Co-rich chromite catalysts calcined at both temperatures (450 and 685 °C), suggesting the formation of pure CoCr2O4, in agreement with XRD measurements. Nevertheless, the fact that the Co oxide phase was not detected in the XRD spectra of Co-rich catalysts can also indicate that the Co oxide amount in this catalyst is low enough for not being identiﬁed or that Co distribution within the spinel structure is quite homogeneous and is likely well incorporate inside the spinel framework. All in all, the results obtained by XRD and HRTEM measurements on the catalysts calcined at 450 ºC seem to point out that CoCr2O4 spinel phase is presented in all catalysts, whereas some Cr and Co oxides are presented in the un-modified one, and even more amount in the Cr-rich one. This could be due to the excess of Cr, which would displace the Co out of the spinel structure, and also form Cr oxide. The later would be favoured in the un-modified catalyst and even more in the Cr-rich catalyst. Nevertheless, in the Co-rich catalyst, the Co excess seems to be well incorporated in the spinel structure (forming a pure CoCr2O4 spinel phase), which could be one of the reasons for the better performance of this catalyst, as will be shown later. Regarding the influence of the calcination temperature, the XRD pattern of catalysts calcined at 450 °C exhibited weaker and wider diffraction peaks than that of the catalysts calcined at higher temperature (685 °C), Fig. 3, suggesting that a high calcination temperature gives rise to a higher crystallinity [44] and to higher average crystallite sizes. The values of crystallinity and average crystal size (by Scherrer equation), confirmed these assumptions, as shown in Table 2. Finally, the lattice parameters “a”, which were calculated using the reference pattern of cubic spinel cobalt CoCr2O4 (JCPDS 22–1084), are in good correlation with literature [17,37–39]. This parameter can give an idea about the insertion of cations into the spinel structure [6,29], knowing that the radii of Co2+, Co3+ and Cr3+ are 72 pm, 69 pm and 76 pm [9]. According to the literature, an enhancement of unit-cell volume (lattice parameter a) will be observed if the substitution of Co3+ by Cr3+/6+ (Oh) takes place and with calcination temperature increase [6,9,10]. This was notably observed for Co-rich catalyst (comparing with un-modified catalyst), which showed a slight enhancement of lattice parameter a, Table 2, probably attributed to the increase of Cr6+ species amount. This suggestion was confirmed by XPS results in the next section. Table 2 also shows the average particle size of each catalyst as estimated from the HRTEM images (from a minimum sample of 100 particles in each case). It must be noted the good correlation between these data and the textural properties of the catalysts discussed above, since those catalysts with higher average particles size in Table 2 are those presenting lower BET surface area and total pore volume in Table 1. Thus, the lower particle size was observed for the un-modified catalyst, among the three catalysts, and for those calcined at lower temperature, evidencing again the strong sintering taking place at 685ºC. On the other hand, the average particle size showed the same trend as crystallinity in these catalysts. 3.1.3 X-Ray Photo-electron Spectroscopy (XPS) and H2-Temperature Programmed Reduction (H2-TPR): surface and redox properties The chemical surface composition and chemical state of the Co-rich and un-modified catalysts were evaluated by XPS analyses. The surface concentrations (at%) of Co, Cr, and O elements are presented in Table 3. The XPS spectra of Cr 2p, Co 2p and O 1 s of un-modified, Co-rich and Cr-rich catalysts calcined at 450 °C are shown in Fig. 5. Two Cr species can be found by curve deconvolution, Fig. 5(a), assigned to Cr3+ and Cr6+. For un-modified CoCr2O4 catalyst, the binding energies (B.E.) values are 576.3 and 578 eV, whereas for Co-rich and Cr-rich catalysts, the values are 575.0 and 576.9 eV and 576.3 and 578.3 eV, respectively [45]. In addition, the deconvolution procedure of Co 2p spectra, Fig. 5(b), was partially based on the fitting method suggested by Biesinger et al. [46]. The B.E. values of Co3+ and Co2+ cations contributions were identified around 780.7 and 782.4 eV for un-modified catalyst, while those for Co-rich and Cr-rich catalysts are 779.1 and 780.8 eV and 780.8 and 782.7 eV, respectively [47]. The dark blue line in Fig. 5(b) corresponds to satellite peak of Co 2p at 785 eV, which is an evidence of the presence of Co2+ species in octahedral sites. The higher the peak, the more Co2+ species are present on the catalyst surface [48–50]. It is also interesting to mention that the comparison between both surface and bulk analysis seems to indicate that the surface of un-modified and Co-rich catalysts is enriched in Cr, while the bulk is enriched in Co, according to the lower Co/Cr at. ratio calculated by XPS (Table 3) with respect to ICP results (Table 1). Similar bulk and surface Co/Cr ratios were observed for Cr-rich catalyst. However, the low amount of Co on Cr-rich catalyst surface (Table 3) seems to indicate that the surface of this catalyst is also enriched in Cr. Moreover, a higher increase of surface Cr6+ sites (vs. bulk) and a higher Cr6+/Cr3+ surface ratio (0.86, 0.78 and 0.66 for Co-rich, un-modified and Cr-rich catalysts, respectively) were evidenced on the catalyst modified with Co, in agreement with a previous work [7], where this ratio was increased by decreasing the relative Cr/Co content in the catalysts. Thus, it can be concluded that with decreasing Cr content, the amount of Cr6+ at the surface increased, Table 3, which can play an important role in toluene oxidation since the VOCs reaction rate seems to depend on the surface density of Cr6+ [6]. XPS results also showed that the amount of Co3+ is lower on Co-rich catalyst than that observed on un-modified and Cr-rich catalysts, all calcined at 450 °C (Table 3), suggesting the substitution of Co3+ by Cr3+/6+ (Oh) [50], as previously pointed by the enhancement of the lattice parameter “a” observed by XRD measurements (Table 2). Moreover, a higher amount of cobalt was clearly evidenced on the surface of Co-rich catalysts, with respect to the un-modified and Cr-rich ones, which means that more active sites are available for the oxidation reaction. On the other hand, the amount of surface lattice oxygen (Olattice) and adsorbed oxygen onto the surface oxygen vacancies and oxygen-containing groups such as hydroxyl species (Oads) was also calculated from O1s spectra, Fig. 5(c). Note that the Olattice are identified at lower binding energy, around 529.2 eV, whereas the Oads are located at around 531.3 eV [51,52]. A significant shift into lower binding energies in Cr 2p, Co 2p, and O 1 s spectra appears for Co-rich catalyst, which could be attributed to the different calibration method with C1s spectra. A slight increase of surface-active oxygen species was evidenced for Co-rich catalyst compared to that presented on the surface of un-modified and Cr-rich catalysts, Table 3. These adsorbed and lattice oxygen molecules play an important role in toluene oxidation, according to the above-mentioned MvK redox mechanism [5,25–28]. Generally, in the low temperature region, surface adsorbed oxygen species are involved in the reaction to oxidize the adsorbed toluene or intermediates, whereas at higher temperatures surface lattice oxygen are activated and can participate in the oxidation of toluene. Moreover, it must also be noted that, in terms of Co3+/Co2+ surface ratio this value was 0.51, 0.95 and 1.24 for the Co-rich, un-modified and Cr-rich catalysts, respectively, calcined at 450 ºC, indicating that abundant Co2+ species are presented on Co-rich catalyst. Given that the presence of Co2+ species is reported to be accompanied by the oxygen vacancies and the oxygen mobility [53–55], the obtained ratios evidence that, in the case of the cobalt chromite catalysts the enhanced catalytic performance of the Co-rich catalyst calcined at 450 ºC (as shown below) could be also attributed to the oxygen vacancies exist in this catalyst. Thus, the Co-rich catalyst exhibit a better oxygen ability, since the oxygen vacancies can enhance the adsorption of gaseous oxygen, promoting the formation of active adsorbed oxygen species, which are typically linked to a better catalytic performance of cobalt oxide catalysts [54–57]. The XPS measurements were also carried out for the Co-rich catalyst calcined at higher temperature (685 °C) in order to evaluate the influence of calcination temperature on redox properties. The Cr 2p, Co 2p and O1s XPS profiles, which are presented in Fig. 6(a-c), were similar to those of the Co-rich catalyst at low calcination temperature. Concerning Cr 2p spectrum, Fig. 5(a) and 6 (a), a higher amount of Cr6+ ions and higher Cr6+/Cr3+ surface ratio (1.34) seem to be present on the surface of this latter Co-rich catalyst compared to the catalysts calcined at 450 °C, according to the relatively lower Co/Cr at. ratio obtained by XPS for this catalyst calcined at 685 ºC (Table 3). These Cr6+ species play an essential role in the oxidation reaction [6,9,10], as mentioned in the introduction. Cr6+ would infiltrate in Oh sites, improving the catalytic properties since Oh are surface-exposed. According to the quantitative analysis of O 1 s profiles, Fig. 6(c), the amount of adsorbed oxygen (Oads) significantly increased for Co-rich catalyst calcined at high temperature (685 °C) compared to that of the catalysts calcined at 450 °C, which indicates that a higher calcination temperature provides more surface-active oxygen species, Table 3. Nevertheless, the surface Co3+/Co2+ ratio increased to 0.66 on the Co-rich catalyst after calcination at 685 ºC, suggesting that the better catalytic performance of this catalyst (as shown below) is rather attributed to the Cr6+ and Oads species, which are significantly increased after calcination at high temperature. Moreover, H2-TPR measurement was performed to evaluate the redox properties of the catalysts, which is considered as one of the most important features of this kind of catalysts for VOCs oxidation reactions, and for toluene in particular [10,11]. The H2-TPR profiles for un-modified and Co-/Cr-rich catalysts calcined at 450 °C are presented in Fig. 7(a). The three catalysts presented reduction profiles with similar peaks patterns in certain temperatures ranges, starting at 96–101 ºC, also showing similarities with those profiles reported on different spinel CoCr2O4 catalysts in literature [7,10,58]. The H2-TPR plots have been divided into two regions: i) low-temperature reduction (from room temperature to 300 ºC), likely associated with redox active sites on the catalyst surface, and thus most interesting from the catalytic point of view; and ii) high-temperature reduction (above 300 ºC), mainly attributed to sub-surface and bulk reduction processes. In the former region, the reduction peaks between 100 ºC and 300 °C are typically attributed in the literature to the reduction of surface Cr6+ to Cr3+ [7,10,38,58,59]. However, these peaks were attributed by some authors to the chemisorption of hydrogen on coordinatively unsaturated Cr3+ species and not to the reduction of chromium species [10,60,61]. On the other hand, the reduction of Co3+ species can also take place at such low temperatures, as reported by Baidya et al. [60], who performed H2-TPR measurements on Cr/Co3O4 with different Cr concentrations and found that the higher the Cr content, the higher the reduction temperature in this region. This is also observed in the present case since, among the three catalysts, Co-rich catalyst (Co-CoCr2O4) requires the lowest temperature for the first reduction peak (195 ºC). In the cases of un-modified and Cr-rich catalysts (CoCr2O4 and Cr-CoC3O4, respectively), the higher Cr content may decrease the reducibility of Co3+, thus increasing the reduction temperature. Besides, the hydrogen consumption taking place at very low temperature (below 200 ºC) has also been attributed by the group of Li et al. [7] to the reduction of surface oxygen species. In the present work, the Co-rich catalyst showed slightly higher Cr6+/Cr3+ at. ratio and concentration of surface oxygen species by XPS (Table 3), which could also explain the left-shift of the low-temperature reduction peak in this catalyst with respect to the others. However, given the identification of CoCr2O4 spinel as the main phase detected by XRD and TEM and the significant amount of surface Cr6+ found by XPS, the main contributing reduction process to the low-temperature peaks is likely the reduction of Cr6+ to Cr3+. Then at temperatures higher than 300 ºC in Fig. 7(a), several reduction peaks can be observed that can be attributed to many features, for example, to the reduction of Co2O3, that usually takes place in two consecutive steps: Co3+ (Co3O4) → Co2+ (CoO) and Co2+ (CoO) → Co0 (metal). This cobalt oxide reduction is reported to be fully accomplished at c.a. 500 ºC for pure Co2O3 [7,38,62], or at higher temperatures, up to more than 750 ºC, for cobalt chromite compounds [7,59,62], like in the present work (peaks up to 597, 690 and 725 ºC for Co-rich, un-modified and Cr-rich catalysts, respectively). Indeed, the observed shift of the cobalt oxide reduction peaks to higher temperatures with the increase of Cr content is in agreement with the literature on Co-Cr-containing catalysts [7,62]. Besides, the reduction of the Cr2O3 content (as evidenced by XRD and TEM) can be overlapped at 300–500 ºC, as shown by Zaki et al. [61], and the peaks observed at very high temperatures (above 750 ºC) could be attributed to the reduction of Cr3+ to lower oxidation states, up to metallic state, according to literature [7,10,58,61]. Although the full reduction of the catalysts was not completed in any case up to 900ºC ( Fig. 8), it can be observed that the degree of reducibility, which is related to the amount of catalyst active sites, remains relatively low, below 22% in all cases, by considering the H2 consumed at temperatures below 300ºC with respect to the total amount of H2 consumed in the whole TPR range, as can be estimated from the H2 consumption quantification in Table 4. Among the three catalysts calcined at 450 ºC, Co-CoCr2O4 showed the highest one in the whole studied temperature range (9.44 mmolH2 g−1), which denotes the important presence of bulk cobalt oxide in this catalyst. However, the catalytic activity is rather determined by the redox reactions on the surface and, in the corresponding low-temperature range (temperatures below 300 ºC), the un-modified catalyst seems to present the highest reduction peaks (Fig. 7(a)) and the highest hydrogen consumption (Table 4), with 1.28 mmolH2 g−1, vs. 0.81 and 0.93 mmolH2 g−1 for Co- and Cr-rich catalysts. Nevertheless, it should be noted that the un-modified catalyst also showed a significantly higher surface area (103 m2 g−1) with respect to the Co- and Cr-rich ones (74 m2 g−1 both), and this is expected to strongly influence the surface-sensitive reduction processes. Indeed, by normalizing per catalyst surface area, the low-temperature hydrogen consumption of Co-rich catalyst (10.9 µmolH2 m−2) is not significantly less than that of the others (11.5 and 12.6 µmolH2 m−2 for un-modified and Cr-rich catalyst). The H2-TPR profiles were also measured for the Co-rich and un-modified catalysts after calcination at 685 ºC and are shown in Fig. 7(b). Both catalysts present much lower peak heights than those obtained after calcination at 450 ºC. This is also evident from the total hydrogen consumption values in Table 4, which are much lower (5.77 and 1.29 mmolH2 g−1 for Co-rich and un-modified catalysts in the whole temperature range). Indeed, in the case of the un-modified CoCrO4 catalyst, most of the reduction peaks vanished, especially those at temperatures below 300 ºC. This negative effect of the calcination temperature on the H2-TPR profiles has been also reported in other works on chromite-based catalysts [10,61], and it can be attributed to the higher crystal and particle sizes and the lower surface area of the catalysts calcined at high temperature, as evidenced in Sections 3.1.1 and 3.1.2. However, in the case of the Co-CoCrO4 catalyst, it is noteworthy that all reduction peaks, including those related to Cr6+ reduction on the surface (< 300 ºC), are still found in Fig. 7(b), without any significant shift with respect to those observed in Fig. 7(a). Indeed, although the hydrogen consumption at low temperature (0.39 mmolH2 g−1) unavoidably decreased with respect to that of the catalyst calcined at 450 ºC (0.81 mmolH2 g−1), it still remained at a significant level (around 50%). This permanent reducibility of the Co-rich catalyst after calcination at high temperature is likely associated with the significant enhancement of the Cr6+/Cr3+ at. ratio and surface oxygen concentration experienced in this case, as shown in Table 3. In conclusion, the Co-rich catalyst presents a higher reducibility with respect to the un-modified and Cr-rich catalysts (general shift of all reduction peaks to the left), and a higher stability, with a significant hydrogen consumption at low temperature even after calcination at 685 ºC, and this is likely attributed to a positive interaction between Co oxides and cobalt chromite (HRTEM images, Fig. 4(c)) and a more favorable surface composition (XPS, Table 3) in this catalyst. 3.2 Toluene catalytic test The catalytic performance of un-modified (CoCr2O4) and Co- and Cr-rich (Co-CoCr2O4 and Cr-CoCr2O4, respectively) catalysts calcined at 450 °C was evaluated in the total oxidation of toluene (Fig. 8, Table 5), which acted as a model reaction for VOCs oxidation. The catalysts calcined at 685 °C were also tested under the same operating conditions. In addition, the catalytic stability was evaluated by performing three consecutive catalytic runs for each catalyst on toluene total oxidation (not shown), which showed a variability of 6.3% and thus are also a good measure of the repeatability of these measurements. The catalyst stabilization after the first run was clearly observed and no appreciable deactivation was detected after three consecutive catalytic runs. The toluene conversion as a function of reaction temperature (light-off curves) during the third catalytic run (cooling ramp) is shown in Fig. 8. The values of T50 and T90, which correspond to the temperature for 50% and 90% conversion of toluene, are presented in Table 5. All catalysts presented a similar catalytic trend, increasing toluene catalytic conversion with an increase in the reaction temperature, as expected. No other final by-products (such as CO) than CO2 and H2O were detected, which indicates the total oxidation of toluene over both un-modified and Co-/Cr-rich cobalt chromite catalysts. From the profiles as well as the T90 data, the catalytic activity of the catalysts followed the order of Co-CoCr2O4 685 °C > CoCr2O4 685 °C > Co-CoCr2O4 450 °C > > Cr-CoCr2O4 685 °C ≈ Cr-CrCr2O4 450 °C > CoCr2O4 450 °C. Even for Co-CoCr2O4 685 °C, the obtained T90 value, 247ºC, is significantly higher than those typically reported for catalysts based on Au or Platinum-group metals, as expected [63]. However, interestingly, the obtained catalytic performance outperforms that of most toluene oxidation studies recently published using non-noble metal catalysts (see Table 6) [16,28,44,64–72], including the previously reported CoCr2O4 catalyst [16]. In some cases, like CoMn2O4 [73], MnO2 [69] or La0.8Ce0.2MnO3/CeO2 [70], the light-off temperature seemed to be lower than in the present work, but the results must be compared upon similar inlet toluene concentration and WHSV values, since a decrease of any of these two parameters is expected to decrease the light-off temperature as reported, for instance, by Chen et al. [68] and Zhang et al. [74]. The only non-noble metal catalysts with better performance under similar operation conditions were a Co3+-rich cobalt oxide [5] and CuMn2O4 [74] catalysts. However, the catalytic results obtained herein are promising by taking into account that the specific surface area of Co-rich CoCr2O4 calcined at 685 ºC (only 9 m2 g−1) is much lower than that of the previously mentioned catalysts (58.5 and 144.0 m2 g−1, respectively). This denotes a good intrinsic catalytic activity of the proposed cobalt chromite, which would potentially improve its performance upon upgrading of the textural and morphological properties and by developing supported-cobalt chromites based catalysts. 3.2.1 Influence of Co- and Cr-enrichment These catalytic results showed that the catalysts modified with additional Co cations were the most active ones, even though these catalysts had lower specific surface area than the Cr-rich and un-modified ones. These finding can be attributed to the excess of cobalt amount, which seems to favour the formation of pure CoCr2O4 spinel phase without the presence of a second phase like on the other catalysts, and to its higher low-temperature reducibility, according to XRD, TEM and H2-TPR results. Besides, the local Cr enrichment on the catalyst surface and the higher amount of surface Cr6+, Oads and oxygen vacancies, as evidenced by XPS results, contributes to the higher activity of these Co-rich catalysts, considering that more active sites are available for the oxidation reaction. Thus, the cation addition appears to be a key parameter for catalytic process efficiency since, whatever the preparation conditions used, the Co-rich catalysts have shown the best performances. 3.2.2 Calcination temperature influence The Co-rich catalyst calcined at 685 °C was even more active than the same catalyst calcined at 450 °C, which suggests that the calcination in air atmosphere has an important influence on the toluene oxidation catalytic activity, which was also observed for un-modified and Cr-rich catalysts. Indeed, it reached 50% of conversion at around 235 °C, compared to 314 °C for the Co-rich catalyst calcined at 450 °C, and 251 and 253 °C for the un-modified and Cr-rich catalysts calcined at 685 °C, respectively (Table 5). According to XRD and TEM results, the calcination affects the spinel phase crystallinity and particles size by increasing them (Table 2), resulting in a decrease of the specific surface area (as evidenced by N2-sorption data, Table 1), which can be linked to the substitution of Co3+ by Cr6+/3+ in octahedral sites (as shown by XPS data, Table 3). Moreover, XPS measurements confirmed that the calcination allowed the increase in Oads amount as well as a higher presence of Cr6+ on the catalyst’ surface. Octahedral sites exposed at the surface were expected to play an important role in the reaction mechanism, likely turning into the key feature for toluene total oxidation. Thus, the results obtained in the catalyst characterisation suggest that the higher catalytic activity of the Co-rich catalyst calcined at high temperature (685 °C) could be mostly associated with the increase of Oads and Cr6+ amounts on the outermost surface as well as to the preservation of a good catalyst reducibility and the intimate contact between the Co oxides and cobalt chromite. However, according to the previous state-of-the-art discussion, both the catalyst formulation and its preparation conditions should be further optimized in search of the best surface composition and redox properties possible with the least possible penalty in terms of surface area and particle size. 3.2.3 Steam effect In order to evaluate the catalytic performance of the best-performing catalyst, Co-rich CoCr2O4 calcined at 685ºC, under more realistic conditions, 5 vol% H2O was introduced into the reaction system along with 1000 ppm toluene at 280ºC. Fig. 9 shows that toluene conversion was maintained at 100% in the absence of water and it decreased after steam introduction, denoting an inhibiting effect of water on the catalyst due to the competitive adsorption of toluene and H2O molecules on the active sites, as typically observed in previous works where the water effect was also investigated [5,68,73,74]. However, toluene conversion still remained stable at around 80% in the presence of water, at least for 16 h. This conversion is even higher than that reported in previous studies under similar operation conditions [5,68], and could be enhanced by decreasing the WHSV, as showed in some other works [73,74]. Finally, after switching again to water-free reaction conditions, the catalyst recovered its initial activity reaching c.a. 100% conversion. Thus, the proposed Co-rich cobalt chromite shows a good stability and tolerance in the presence of steam which makes it potential for particle application. 4 Conclusions Seven types of characterization measurements have been conducted to corroborate the relationship between physico-chemical, surface, redox and catalytic properties of synthetized catalysts. Spinel-type un-modified and Co-/Cr-rich cobalt chromite catalysts were efficiently synthetized for the first time by sol-gel method using liquid propionic acid as a chelating agent and solvent. The influence of Co and Cr addition and calcination temperature on toluene total catalytic oxidation was consequently evaluated. The spinel-type cobalt chromite materials were proven to be promising catalysts showing a high activity to toluene removal, which increases by adding Co species to the catalyst and by increasing the calcination temperature. Indeed, among the three catalysts calcined at 450 °C, the Co-rich one has shown the best activity, which could notably ascribe to the formation of a pure CoCr2O4 spinel phase, the higher available cobalt and Cr6+ content on the catalyst surface and higher reducibility. Moreover, the calcination temperature increases spinel phase crystallinity and particle sizes, decreasing the materials’ specific surface area. Thus, the activity of Co-rich catalyst calcined at 685 °C, which results to be the most active catalyst, could be notably related to the amount of surface Cr6+ ions and enhanced surface oxygen concentration, as well as the catalyst stability in terms of reducibility, according to characterization and catalytic test measurements. Thus, it seems that the toluene oxidation activity of cobalt chromite-based catalysts seems to be mainly determined by their surface composition and redox properties rather than by their physico-chemical and textural properties. Moreover, the catalytic activity and stability of the catalyst has also been validated in the presence of steam. Thus, the results obtained in this work, taking into account a significant margin of further improvement in terms of synthesis parameters optimization, show cobalt chromite-type catalysts as one of the most competitive materials for toluene oxidation. coredata.dc:description: Un-supported spinel-type cobalt chromite catalysts were synthetized by propionic acid-mediated sol-gel method and tested for toluene oxidation. The influence of the Co and Cr content and the preparation conditions on physico-chemical, surface and catalytic properties for this reaction has been for the first time evaluated. Co-rich CoCr2O4 was the most active catalyst, likely due to the formation of a single CoCr2O4 spinel phase, a favorable surface composition and higher low-temperature reducibility. Besides, the increase of the calcination temperature, despite worsening textural properties, also has a promoting effect on the catalytic activity by preserving a suitable reducibility and further enhancing the surface properties. Surface Cr6+ ions and adsorbed oxygens (Oads), which are more abundant in the most efficient catalyst (Co-rich catalyst calcined at 685 °C), seem to play an important role on toluene oxidation reaction. These findings may open potential strategies in the development of efficient and economically competitive catalysts for elimination of VOCs like toluene.
coredata.dc:title: Low-temperature gas-phase toluene catalytic combustion over modified CoCr2O4 spinel catalysts: Effect of Co/Cr content and calcination temperature
